The Child Care for Economic Recovery Act will help working families & support ongoing employment by:

- Helping more low- and middle-income families afford care
- Supporting providers struggling financially from coronavirus
- Increasing federal investment in child care
(3/3)

The Child Care is Essential Act creates a $50 billion Child Care Stabilization Fund for grant funding to child care providers to stabilize and help the child care sector safely reopen. The bill also keeps child care affordable by providing relief from copayments & tuition. (2/3)

The pandemic has made it even harder for families to access quality, affordable child care. 

Today, I was proud to support two bills offering relief for families and providers and support for the safe reopening of our economy. #SaveChildCare (1/3) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EeITI1xXoAAag-m.png

Diseases do not respect borders. In order to avoid a future where the United States is once again ill-equipped to battle a highly transmittable virus, we need to invest more in organizations like CEPI and work productively with our allies starting today. 9/9

The Administration needs to reengage with the international community. We, as Americans, stand to gain a great deal from working with our global partners on everything from vaccine development to distribution to the study of zoonotic disease. /8

CEPI is at the forefront of the search for not only a vaccine but also signs of the inevitable next pandemic. They are focused on the science, w/ experts from across the globe on the cutting edge of pandemic response research to better prepare us for future viral outbreaks. /7
By joining CEPI, the United States would be taking a proactive step towards fortifying itself against viruses like COVID-19. /6
Unless we take decisive action to change our present and future course of action, we will again be faced with unnecessarily high death tolls and community spread when the next pandemic strikes. /5

This particular legislation, which I also helped pass through the HEROES Act in May, has ramifications beyond those of COVID-19. What has been painstakingly clear is that we, as a nation, were woefully unprepared for a pandemic of this proportion. /4

Thus far, the Administration has failed to meet this moment ‚Äì 5 months in and 150,000 American lives lost, and we are still without a national testing strategy or a global plan for large-scale vaccine production and equitable access around the world. /3

As we continue to face this global pandemic, it's critical that the United States actively engage w/ the international community, including the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), to rapidly and safely develop, manufacture, & distribute a COVID-19 vaccine. /2
